data.title: Performance issue with MonoGame 3.3.*
Implement TextureCube.GetData for DirectX
data.body:
Most of the time you probably don't need this method, but when you do, you do...

(In my engine / editor, I'm rendering a skybox (either from a `TextureCube` or a procedural shader) into a `RenderTargetCube`, then using `TextureCube.GetData` to extract the rendered data and convert it to spherical harmonics, and finally using the spherical harmonics to render a directional ambient term that matches up nicely with the skybox.)

Importer 'TextureImporter' had unexpected failure!
System.DllNotFoundException: Unable to load DLL 'FreeImage': The specified modul
e could not be found. (Exception from HRESULT: 0x8007007E)
   at FreeImageAPI.FreeImage.GetFileType(String filename, Int32 size)
   at FreeImageAPI.FreeImage.LoadEx(String filename, FREE_IMAGE_LOAD_FLAGS flags
, FREE_IMAGE_FORMAT& format)
   at FreeImageAPI.FreeImage.LoadEx(String filename)
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.TextureImporter.Import(String fil
ename, ContentImporterContext context) in c:\Users\danzel\Code\Simpulls\MonoGame
\MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline\TextureImporter.cs:line 85
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.ContentImporter`1.Microsoft.Xna.F
ramework.Content.Pipeline.IContentImporter.Import(String filename, ContentImport
erContext context) in c:\Users\danzel\Code\Simpulls\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework.
Content.Pipeline\ContentImporter.cs:line 45

oGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline\Builder\PipelineManager.cs:line 575

Solution was to install the x64 version of vs 2012 c++ redistributable
http://www.microsoft.com/en-NZ/download/details.aspx?id=30679

We should probably have a nicer error for this if we can, spent ages bashing at this! (Dependency Walker told me what the missing dll was)

data.title: Fix logic for applying texture effect parameters
data.body:
This essentially undoes #3385, and applies a much simpler fix.

The first 2 commits just add tests; the last of the 3 commits implements the fixes.

A couple of things to note:
- The `stateKey`-based system I added in #3385 to decide whether to apply textures from effect parameters wasn't correct. If you switched between multiple effects, but didn't explicitly call `textureParameter.SetValue` each time, textures wouldn't be re-applied. I think this probably caused #3549.
- If you are using a custom effect with `SpriteBatch`, and that custom effect uses a couple of textures, then XNA always sets the texture you specify in `spriteBatch.Draw` into the first texture slot, even if you have explicitly set that texture to something else in your effect parameters. This was the part I didn't understand before - but I've added a test for it now. Because of this, I can remove the `stateKey` stuff from `EffectPass`.

So this PR changes the logic to: **always use the textures specified in effect parameters (`null` or otherwise), but if you're using `SpriteBatch` then ensure `Textures[0]` is set to the texture you passed to `spriteBatch.Draw`, regardless of what the effect parameter values are.**

Once again, I'd appreciate feedback on this one. Especially after I got it wrong last time :) But if it looks good, then we should merge it as soon as possible, given that it (hopefully) fixes quite a big bug.

data.title: Sporadic draw call timings
data.body:
I have put together a small piece of code to reproduce the problem that can be found [here](https://gist.github.com/xposure/bff23116b9e8a2e00644) along with my log output and dxdiag.

The problem is that with a default game window and nothing running on my machine, I get draw calls at a steady 16ms as I would expect. Now if I launch chrome and start playing a youtube video the draw calls go up to 33ms and in addition frequently spike up to 50+ ms and make my game appear jittery.

More Info
-  Chrome 40.0.2214.111 m
-  YouTube HTML5 Video Player
-  Happens in both debug and release and regardless if the window has focus and if the debugger isn't attached
-  Using the latest code from https://github.com/mono/MonoGame.git
-  Project is set to .NET Framework 4, Output type as Console (for Console.WriteLine)

data.title: Added test cases for empty XML datatypes
data.body:
Updated deserialisation to support empty XML elements for all datatypes

E.g. 

``` xml
<Vector2/>
<float/>
```

 and 

``` xml
<Vector2></Vector2>
<float></float>
```

Tested all data type variants that have intermediate serialisers

data.title: Fix for linux exit errors 2, 3, 4 from #3540
data.body: Fix for linux exit errors 2, 3, 4 from #3540

data.title: Android orientation lock
data.body: Simple and useful feature. Many Android devices are very sensitive when it comes to rotation. If the user shakes the device the rotation might change, so this is very useful if you use accelerometer in your game. Just lock the rotation while the game is playing and unlock once the game is paused/stopped.

Fix serialization and deserialization of empty lists
data.body: (Hopefully) fixes an issue that @DDReaper encountered.

data.title: Use 32-bit MojoShader DLL for old content processors
data.body: Fixes #3004.

data.title: GraphicsDevice Draw call parameter validation
data.body:
Adds parameter validation for:
- `DrawPrimitives`
- `DrawIndexedPrimitives`
- `DrawUserPrimitives`
- `DrawUserIndexedPrimitives`

I don't know if this is controversial - we have parameter validation elsewhere in MG, but until now the `Draw*` methods didn't have it. Obviously there is a (tiny) performance overhead. As @tomspilman has said elsewhere, it's a pity that VS doesn't make it easy to switch between debug / release assemblies, which would be the best of both worlds.

I don't think `Debug.Assert` is a viable replacement, since (I assume) very few developers build MG from source (or at least, that will be true once there are more frequent MG releases), and so very few developers are using the debug assemblies.

**EDIT** Forgot to say that #3125 was the trigger for this PR. However, from what I've found, XNA doesn't actually throw an exception when the `VertexDeclaration` size doesn't match the vertex data size in `DrawUser[Indexed]Primitives`. That's verified in a unit test.

data.title: Performance issues calling Threading.EnsureUIThread
data.body:
Below is an Instrument trace (30sec) from our app on an iPad Air (1st gen). I noticed a significant amount of time (relatively speaking) spent in `Threading.EnsureUIThread()` for each draw call. It seems to be wastefull to spend ~7.5% of each drawcall on making sure we are on the UI thread.

Should it be MonoGame responsibility to ensure the caller is on the UI thread? Could it be something that is only active in debug builds and properly documented (anyone who uses OpenGL should be aware of threading issues)?

![screen shot 2015-02-16 at 6 13 56 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/502478/6222399/c61afe22-b607-11e4-8206-e86a1bf04d96.png)

data.title: PNG codec
data.body:
First shot at platform-independent implementation of the PNG image standard.  Uses source from the BSD-licensed [ZLIB.NET](http://www.componentace.com/zlib_.NET.htm) for the DEFLATE algorithm.  Issue mono#2424

`public Texture2D Read(Stream inputStream, GraphicsDevice graphicsDevice)` (PngReader.cs)
`public Stream Write(Texture2D texture2D)` (PngWriter.cs)

Some limitations at this stage:
- Bit depths that are not multiples of 8 are unsupported (most PNG's are 8-bit per sample though)
- The ZLIB.NET DEFLATE algorithm fails on a very small number of PNG's (like [this](http://www.deviantart.com/art/Royal-Entrance-180978838) one for instance)
- Some PNG's that are technically malformed (invalid pixel data array length) will crash the reader, even though other PNG decoders (like Picasa) will decode them without complaint.
- The PNG writer ignores alpha values at the moment.
- Should be thread-safe but haven't tested it yet.

These issues will be addressed in the future.

data.title: Newest build does not compile on Linux
data.body:
I have a suspicion that something was overwritten by accident, since after a clean pull and Protobuild, the Linux solution does not compile.

> /usr/lib/mono/4.5/Microsoft.Common.targets: Error: Cannot copy /home/user/workspace/MonoGame/Test/Assets/ReferenceImages/RasterizerState/VisualTestFillMode_Wireframe_.png to /home/user/workspace/MonoGame/Test/bin/Linux/AnyCPU/Release/Assets/ReferenceImages/RasterizerState/VisualTestFillMode_Wireframe_.png, as the source file doesn't exist. (MonoGame.Tests.Linux)

The image does exist, but it named "VisualTestFillMode_Wire**F**rame_.png" rather than what it should be called.

data.title: MonoDevelop/XamarinStudio add-in or high-level steps for "For now build from source for Linux and Mac"
data.body:
This has nearly caused me to abandon MonoGame altogether. I was attracted to it due to it being cross-platform and was hoping to create a game on my Mac or Linux machine that could later be ported to Windows, but the lack of documentation on a simple environment setup with version 3.2 (which was released nearly a year ago) is making me weary of moving forward with my idea.

Could someone in the community please create an add-in for "The new addins for MonoDevelop/XamarinStudio are coming soon!", or if the building from source workaround is sufficient then please provide extra documentation as to what "For now build from source for Linux and Mac" means at:

http://www.monogame.net/downloads/

There is no mention of building from source in: 

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10388097/monogame-mac-installation-instructions

Also, any non-bundled, platform-specific, MonoGame sample games with Xamarin build steps would be a great morale booster to newer game developers such as myself. Something this simple could greatly increase adoption of the framework and the growth of the community.
